newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Dominica sees disaster if banana exports disrupted.
newsitem.headline: Dominica sees disaster if banana exports disrupted.

text.p: The tiny island nation of Dominica warned on Thursday of social and political disaster if Latin America-based multinational corporations succeeded in ending preferential treatment for Caribbean banana exports to the European Union.
Ambassador Simon Richards, Dominica's U.N. envoy, was the latest of a number of Caribbean representatives to stress the vital importance of the banana trade.

"In the struggle to save an industry critical to our economic survival, our political stability and our democratic traditions and institutions, we call upon the international community to take note of the very real possibility of social upheaval and political disaster in the region if this challenge to the European Union regime were to succeed," he said.

Richards said the banana industry in the Windward Islands group accounted for less than five percent of world production. The producers were small landowners, and because production costs were relatively high, any attempt to sell their product on the open market "would be suicidal," he said.
Because of this and traditional links, the European Union had established a regime reserving less than 10 percent of its market for bananas from the Caribbean.
"That regime is now under attack from multinationals in Latin America with huge resources augmented by the power, prestige and political might of their national governments."

Alluding to the United States, which backs those banana producers, he said it was incongruous that the same forces at the forefront of efforts to establish democratic institutions and representative governments in certain parts of the world were also engaged in an enterprise which, if successful, was "calculated to destroy the free and democratic way of life in the Eastern Caribbean."
